flow.descriptionCdata:
3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.149b5a49-5077-41f3-b8c8-dd1b5033c358.description=This flow is used to Create Changes.

Inputs
 host - The URL of the ServiceNow instance.
Format\: scheme\://domain
Example\: https\://dev10000.service-now.com
 authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server. The authentication is not preemptive\: a plain request not including authentication info will be made and only when the server responds with a 'WWW-Authenticate' header the client will send required headers. If the server needs no authentication but you specify one in this input the request will work nevertheless. The client cannot choose the authentication method and there is no fallback so you have to know which one you need. If the web application and proxy use different authentication types, these must be specified like in the Example model. 
Default value\: basic
Valid values\: basic, digest, ntlm, kerberos, any, anonymous, "" or a list of valid values separated by comma.
Example\: basic | basic,digest
 username - The ServiceNow username used to perform the request.
 password - The ServiceNow password used to perform the request.
 apiVersion - The API version with which the request will be sent. The call will be made using the latest API version when this input is left empty.
Example\: v1
 requestBody - The string to include in the body of the request, in the format accepted by ServiceNow. In case more Change fields need to be addressed, they can be provided in the "requestBody" input. When a custom body is provided, the values provided in the inputs named "change<field_name>" will be ignored unless their reference is used in the new body.
Example\: {'short_description'\:'Example description','severity'\:'1','assigned_to'\:'46c1293aa9fe1981000dc753e75ebeee','state'\:'4'}
 changeShortDescription - The short description of the Change to be created, in the form of a string. If this input is left empty, the short description of the created Change will be empty.
 changeDescription - The description of the Change to be created, in the form of a string. If this input is left empty, description of the created Change will be empty.
 changeNumber - The number of the Change to be created. Should contain the "CHG" prefix followed by 7 or more digits. If this input is left empty, ServiceNow will automatically assign a number.
Example\: CHG0100001
 changeRequestedBy - The system ID of the entity that requested the Change.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 changeCategory - The Category name in the form of a string.
Example\: Software, Hardware
 changeConfigurationItem - The system ID of the Configuration Item. (CMDB CI)
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 changePriority - The Priority of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 5.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
 changeRisk - The risk of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 5.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
 changeImpact - The impact of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 3.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3
 changeApproval - The Approval status in the form of a string.
Valid values\: approved, requested, not requested yet, rejected
 changeType - The type of the Change in the form of a string.
Example\: Routine, Comprehensive
 changeState - The State of the Change, in the form of a positive integer. Each integer represents an Change State as follows\: 1\=Open, 2\=Work in Progress, 3\=Closed Complete, 4\=Closed Incomplete, 7\=Closed Skipped.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 7
 changeAssignmentGroup - The system ID of the Assignment Group.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 changeAssignedTo - The system ID of the entity to which the Change should be assigned to.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 preemptiveAuth - If this field is "true", authentication info will be sent in the first request. If this is "false" a request with no authentication info will be made and if the server responds with 401 and a header such as WWW-Authenticate\: Basic realm\="myRealm", only then will the authentication info be sent.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 proxyHost - The proxy server used to access the web site.
 proxyPort - The proxy server port. Default value\: 8080. Valid values\: -1, and positive integer values. When the value is '-1' the default port of the scheme, specified in the 'proxyHost', will be used.
 proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy.
 proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the proxyUsername input value.
 trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL/TSL. A certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it.
Default value\: false
Valid values\: true, false
 x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker (Man-In-The-Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option.
Default value\: strict
Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all
 trustKeystore - The pathname of the Java TrustStore file. This contains certificates from other parties that you expect to communicate with, or from Certificate Authorities that you trust to identify other parties. If the protocol (specified by the URL) is not HTTPS or if trustAllRoots is "true" this input is ignored.
Default value\: <OO_Home>/java/lib/security/cacerts
Format\: Java KeyStore (JKS)
 trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If trustAllRoots is false and trustKeystore is empty, trustPassword default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
 connectTimeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in seconds. A timeout value of 0 represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
Format\: an integer representing seconds
Examples\: 10, 20
 socketTimeout - The timeout for waiting for data (a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets), in seconds. A socketTimeout value of 0 represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
Format\: an integer representing seconds
 useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls in a serializable session object therefore they will be available on a branch level (same subflow, same lane). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 keepAlive - Specifies whether to create a shared connection that will be used in subsequent calls. If keepAlive is false, the already open connection will be used and after execution it will close it. The operation will use a connection pool stored in a GlobalSessionObject that will be available throughout the execution (the flow and subflows, between parallel split lanes).
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 connectionsMaxPerRoute - The maximum limit of connections on a per route basis. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections per given route.
Default value\: 2
 connectionsMaxTotal - The maximum limit of connections in total. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections in total.
Default value\: 20
 headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:".
Format\: According to HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
Examples\: Accept\:text/plain
 responseCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP response. If responseCharacterSet is empty, the charset from the 'Content-Type' HTTP response header will be used. If responseCharacterSet is empty and the charset from the HTTP response Content-Type header is empty, the default value will be used. You should not use this for method\=HEAD or OPTIONS.
Default value\: ISO-8859-1
 followRedirects - Specifies whether the HTTP client automatically follows redirects. Redirects explicitly prohibited by the HTTP specification as requiring user intervention will not be followed (redirects on POST and PUT requests that are converted to GET requests). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 requestCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP request body. If contentType is empty, the requestCharacterSet will use the default value. If contentType will include charset (ex.\: "application/json; charset\=UTF-8"), the requestCharacterSet value will overwrite the charset value from contentType input. This should not be provided for method\=GET, HEAD, TRACE
Default value\: ISO-8859-1

Results\:
 returnResult - This will contain the response entity. In case of an error this output will contain the error message.
 document - This will contain the response body.
 exception - In case of success response, this result is empty. In case of failure response, this result contains the java stack trace of the runtime exception.
 statusCode - The HTTP status code.
Format\: 1xx (Informational - Request received, continuing process), 2xx (Success - The action was successfully received, understood, and accepted), 3xx (Redirection - Further action must be taken in order to complete the request), 4xx (Client Error - The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled), 5xx Server Error - The server failed to fulfil an apparently valid request)
Examples\: 200, 404
 responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline.
Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
 systemId - The system ID of the created Change.


Responses
 success - The operation completed without a runtime exception.
 failure - A runtime exception occurred. This may be due to incorrectly formated inputs (headers, proxy, queryParams, url).

Notes\:
1. The reference of the "change<field_name>" inputs should be removed from inside the "requestBody" input when they are deleted.
2. When more Change fields are required, than the ones exposed, you can add them as inputs and insert their reference in the Json found in the "requestBody" input.
3. In order to authenticate using an OAuth token\: 
 3.1. The headers input should contain the following header\: Authorization\:Bearer <OAuth_token>
 3.2. The username and password inputs should remain empty. 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.1d2029b4-c59e-4e22-8852-cac1467e59f3.description=This flow is used to Create Incidents.

Inputs
 host - The URL of the ServiceNow instance.
Format\: scheme\://domain
Example\: https\://dev10000.service-now.com
 authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server. The authentication is not preemptive\: a plain request not including authentication info will be made and only when the server responds with a 'WWW-Authenticate' header the client will send required headers. If the server needs no authentication but you specify one in this input the request will work nevertheless. The client cannot choose the authentication method and there is no fallback so you have to know which one you need. If the web application and proxy use different authentication types, these must be specified like in the Example model. 
Default value\: basic
Valid values\: basic, digest, ntlm, kerberos, any, anonymous, "" or a list of valid values separated by comma.
Example\: basic | basic,digest
 username - The ServiceNow username used to perform the request.
 password - The ServiceNow password used to perform the request.
 apiVersion - The API version with which the request will be sent. The call will be made using the latest API version when this input is left empty.
Example\: v1
 requestBody - The string to include in the body of the request, in the format accepted by ServiceNow. In case more Incident fields need to be addressed, they can be provided in the "requestBody" input. When a custom body is provided, the values provided in the inputs named "incident<field_name>" will be ignored unless their reference is used in the new body.
Example\: {'short_description'\:'Example description','severity'\:'1','assigned_to'\:'46c1293aa9fe1981000dc753e75ebeee','state'\:'4'}
 incidentShortDescription - The short description of the Incident to be created, in the form of a string. If this input is left empty, the short description of the created Incident will be empty.
 incidentNumber - The number of the Incident to be created. Should contain the "INC" prefix followed by 7 or more digits. If this input is left empty, ServiceNow will automatically assign a number.
Example\: INC0100001
 incidentCaller - The system ID of the Caller.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 incidentLocation - The system ID of the Location.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 incidentCategory - The Category name in the form of a string.
Example\: Software, Inquiry / Help
 incidentSubcategory - The Subcategory name in the form of a string.
Example\: Email, Operating System
 incidentImpact - The Impact of the Incident, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 3.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3
 incidentUrgency - The Urgency of the Incident, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 3.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3
 incidentPriority - The Priority of the Incident, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 5.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
 incidentOpenedBy - The system ID of the entity that submitted the Incident.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 incidentContactType - The Contact Type in the form of a string.
Example\: Phone, Email
 incidentState - The State of the Incident, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 7. Each integer represents an Incident State as follows\: 1\=New, 2\=Active, 3\=Awaiting Problem, 4\=Awaiting User Info, 5\=Awaiting Evidence, 6\=Resolved, 7\=Closed.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7
 incidentAssignmentGroup - The system ID of the Assignment Group.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 incidentAssignedTo - The system ID of the entity to which the Incident should be assigned to.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 preemptiveAuth - If this field is "true", authentication info will be sent in the first request. If this is "false" a request with no authentication info will be made and if the server responds with 401 and a header such as WWW-Authenticate\: Basic realm\="myRealm", only then will the authentication info be sent.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 proxyHost - The proxy server used to access the web site.
 proxyPort - The proxy server port. Default value\: 8080. Valid values\: -1, and positive integer values. When the value is '-1' the default port of the scheme, specified in the 'proxyHost', will be used.
 proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy.
 proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the proxyUsername input value.
 trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL/TSL. A certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it.
Default value\: false
Valid values\: true, false
 x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker (Man-In-The-Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option.
Default value\: strict
Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all
 trustKeystore - The pathname of the Java TrustStore file. This contains certificates from other parties that you expect to communicate with, or from Certificate Authorities that you trust to identify other parties. If the protocol (specified by the URL) is not HTTPS or if trustAllRoots is "true" this input is ignored.
Default value\: <OO_Home>/java/lib/security/cacerts
Format\: Java KeyStore (JKS)
 trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If trustAllRoots is false and trustKeystore is empty, trustPassword default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
 connectTimeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in seconds. A timeout value of 0 represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
Format\: an integer representing seconds
Examples\: 10, 20
 socketTimeout - The timeout for waiting for data (a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets), in seconds. A socketTimeout value of 0 represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
Format\: an integer representing seconds
 useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls in a serializable session object therefore they will be available on a branch level (same subflow, same lane). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 keepAlive - Specifies whether to create a shared connection that will be used in subsequent calls. If keepAlive is false, the already open connection will be used and after execution it will close it. The operation will use a connection pool stored in a GlobalSessionObject that will be available throughout the execution (the flow and subflows, between parallel split lanes).
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 connectionsMaxPerRoute - The maximum limit of connections on a per route basis. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections per given route.
Default value\: 2
 connectionsMaxTotal - The maximum limit of connections in total. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections in total.
Default value\: 20
 headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:".
Format\: According to HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
Examples\: Accept\:text/plain
 responseCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP response. If responseCharacterSet is empty, the charset from the 'Content-Type' HTTP response header will be used. If responseCharacterSet is empty and the charset from the HTTP response Content-Type header is empty, the default value will be used. You should not use this for method\=HEAD or OPTIONS.
Default value\: ISO-8859-1
 followRedirects - Specifies whether the HTTP client automatically follows redirects. Redirects explicitly prohibited by the HTTP specification as requiring user intervention will not be followed (redirects on POST and PUT requests that are converted to GET requests). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 requestCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP request body. If contentType is empty, the requestCharacterSet will use the default value. If contentType will include charset (ex.\: "application/json; charset\=UTF-8"), the requestCharacterSet value will overwrite the charset value from contentType input. This should not be provided for method\=GET, HEAD, TRACE
Default value\: ISO-8859-1

Results\:
 returnResult - This will contain the response entity. In case of an error this output will contain the error message.
 document - This will contain the response body.
 exception - In case of success response, this result is empty. In case of failure response, this result contains the java stack trace of the runtime exception.
 statusCode - The HTTP status code.
Format\: 1xx (Informational - Request received, continuing process), 2xx (Success - The action was successfully received, understood, and accepted), 3xx (Redirection - Further action must be taken in order to complete the request), 4xx (Client Error - The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled), 5xx Server Error - The server failed to fulfil an apparently valid request)
Examples\: 200, 404
 responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline.
Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
 systemId - The system ID of the created Incident.


Responses
 success - The operation completed without a runtime exception.
 failure - A runtime exception occurred. This may be due to incorrectly formated inputs (headers, proxy, queryParams, url).

Notes\:
1. The reference of the "incident<field_name>" inputs should be removed from inside the "requestBody" input when they are deleted.
2. When more Incident fields are required, than the ones exposed, you can add them as inputs and insert their reference in the Json found in the "requestBody" input.
3. In order to authenticate using an OAuth token\: 
 3.1. The headers input should contain the following header\: Authorization\:Bearer <OAuth_token>
 3.2. The username and password inputs should remain empty. 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.2119b021-1e8a-49ab-906d-824305cf694f.callout=This flow detects the operating system of a given host, initiates a restart for the host, sleeps for a specified number of seconds and then pings the host to make sure it is reachable again. 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.59946607-698a-44c3-9d75-696823be8def.description=<pre>This flow detects the operating system of a given host, initiates a restart for the host, sleeps for a specified number of seconds and then pings the host to make sure it is reachable again.

Inputs\:
 host - The hostname or IP address of the system to shutdown/restart.
 username - The user to connect to the host.
 password - The password to connect to the host.

Responses\:
 success - Server restart completed successfully.
 failure - An error occurred during the detection of the operating system of the server, during the actual restart process or during the pinging of the server after the restart completed.

Results\:
 returnResult - This is the primary output. When the execution is successful, this will contain information retrieved by the ping step. In the event of a failure, it will contain details about the error.
 osName - This result contains the result of the detection of the operating system for the specified host.
 exception - This result contains information about the cause of the failure.

Note\: 

The are two hidden inputs that allow to specify the number of attempts to ping and the number of seconds that the flow sleeps before each ping.

 nbTries - The number of attempts of pinging the server to make sure it is reachable again.
Default value\: 5
 sleepInterval - The number of seconds the flow sleeps before pinging.
Default value\: 20

In order to use this functionality, the inputs must be added for every step of 'Restart Server'.

If none of the ping attempts suceed, the execution will end with a warning.
</pre>
 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.6b432bef-4870-4098-905a-5d45910a5ea1.description=<pre>
This flow sends, stores or displays a notification message according to your notification type selection. You can use this flow to select how to be notified about the outcome of other flows. 

Inputs\:
 notifyData - The content of the notification message.
 notifyMethod - The notification type. This value is not case sensitive.
Valid values\: Write to File, Email, Display or None
 subject - A summary of the notification content. 
 destination - The destination of the notification. You must specify a value for this input if "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’ or ‘Write to File’.
Valid values\: An email address or a file name
 notificationServer - The email server used to send the notification email message. If "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’, you must specify a value for this input.
 from - The email address of the sender of the notification email message. If "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’, you must specify a value for this input.
 serverPort - The notification service’s server port. This field’s value is used when the "notifyMethod" is ‘Email’, but it is optional.
Default value\: 25
 htmlEmail - The value should be true if the email is in rich text/HTML format. The value should be false to send the email in plain text format.
Default value\: true

Responses\:
 success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
 failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Note\:
 To schedule a flow that uses this flow, you need to supply all the required fields for the used notification method. For example, if "notifyMethod" is set to ‘File’, the "destination" input must also be specified.

Examples\:
 This is a valid input example for storing a notification message to a file\:
 notifyData\: notificationContent
 notifyMethod\: Write to File
 subject\: notificationSubject
 destination\: C\:\Program File\notification.txt
</pre> 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.703d9ac5-1b38-44fc-abab-fb74d4120b97.callout=This flow is used to Update Changes in ServiceNow 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.a3da77ab-0181-4028-8131-9a7683c09f7b.callout=This flow is used to Create Incidents in ServiceNow 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.a6ef188a-e814-4705-84e6-3ee5c1072280.prompt=Notification option\: 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.afed7423-2866-4d76-9b11-f463dc126979.prompt=Notification option\: 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.cd179d47-9b8d-4a40-8625-6e3b7fe24336.callout=This flow sends, stores or displays a notification message according to your notification type selection. You can use this flow to select how to be notified about the outcome of other flows. 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.d456cfd5-5b92-4e29-a21a-3dd0ec5aa1cd.description=This flow is used to retrieve the details of one or more Incidents.

Inputs
 host - The URL of the ServiceNow instance.
Format\: scheme\://domain
Example\: https\://dev10000.service-now.com
 authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server. The authentication is not preemptive\: a plain request not including authentication info will be made and only when the server responds with a 'WWW-Authenticate' header the client will send required headers. If the server needs no authentication but you specify one in this input the request will work nevertheless. The client cannot choose the authentication method and there is no fallback so you have to know which one you need. If the web application and proxy use different authentication types, these must be specified like in the Example model. 
Default value\: basic
Valid values\: basic, digest, ntlm, kerberos, any, anonymous, "" or a list of valid values separated by comma.
Example\: basic | basic,digest
 username - The ServiceNow username used to perform the request.
 password - The ServiceNow password used to perform the request.
 apiVersion - The API version with which the request will be sent. The call will be made using the latest API version when this input is left empty.
Example\: v1
 systemId - The System ID of the Incident for which details should be returned. When this imput is left empty, the flow returns the details of multiple Incidents based on the values assigned to the "sysParamLimi", "sysParamQuery" and "sysParamFields" inputs.
Example\: 71c7ac460f811200ff7eb17ce1050e7a
 sysParamLimit - The maximum number of results to be returned.
Default value\: 10000
 sysParamQuery - A query string used to filter the results.
Example\: urgency\=1
 sysParamFields - A query string used to filter the fields returned in the results.
Example\: short_description,number,sys_id
 preemptiveAuth - If this field is 'true' authentication info will be sent in the first request. If this is 'false' a request with no authentication info will be made and if server responds with 401 and a header like WWW-Authenticate\: Basic realm\="myRealm" only then the authentication info will be sent.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 proxyHost - The proxy server used to access the web site.
 proxyPort - The proxy server port. Default value\: 8080. Valid values\: -1, and positive integer values. When the value is '-1' the default port of the scheme, specified in the 'proxyHost', will be used.
 proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy. The 'authType' input will be used to choose authentication type. The 'Basic' and 'Digest' proxy auth type are supported.
 proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the proxyUsername input value.
 trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL/TSL. A certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it.
Default value\: false
Valid values\: true, false
 x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker(Man In The Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option.
Default value\: strict
Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all
 trustKeystore - The pathname of the Java TrustStore file. This contains certificates from other parties that you expect to communicate with, or from Certificate Authorities that you trust to identify other parties. If the protocol (specified by the 'url') is not 'https' or if trustAllRoots is 'true' this input is ignored.
Default value\: <OO_Home>/java/lib/security/cacerts
Format\: Java KeyStore (JKS)
 trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If trustAllRoots is false and trustKeystore is empty, trustPassword default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
 connectTimeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in seconds. A timeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
Format\: an integer representing seconds
Examples\: 10, 20
 socketTimeout - The timeout for waiting for data (a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets), in seconds. A socketTimeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
Format\: an integer representing seconds
 useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls in a serializable session object therefore they will be available on a branch level (same subflow, same lane). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true,false
 keepAlive - Specifies whether to create a shared connection that will be used in subsequent calls. If keepAlive is false, the already open connection will be used and after execution it will close it. The operation will use a connection pool stored in a GlobalSessionObject that will be available throughout the execution (the flow and subflows, between parallel split lanes).
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 connectionsMaxPerRoute - The maximum limit of connections on a per route basis. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections per given route.
Default value\: 2
 connectionsMaxTotal - The maximum limit of connections in total. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections in total.
Default value\: 20
 followRedirects - Specifies whether the HTTP client automatically follows redirects. Redirects explicitly prohibited by the HTTP specification as requiring user intervention will not be followed (redirects on POST and PUT requests that are converted to GET requests). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:".
Format\: Conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
Examples\: Accept\:text/plain
 responseCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP response. If responseCharacterSet is empty, the charset from the 'Content-Type' HTTP response header will be used. If responseCharacterSet is empty and the charset from the HTTP response Content-Type header is empty, the default value will be used. You should not use this for method\=HEAD or OPTIONS.
Default value\: ISO-8859-1
 queryParams - The list containing query parameters to append to the URL. The names and the values must not be URL encoded unless you specify "queryParamsAreURLEncoded"\=true because if they are encoded and "queryParamsAreURLEncoded"\=false they will get double encoded. The separator between name-value pairs is "&". The query name will be separated from query value by "\=". Note that you need to URL encode at least "&" to "%26" and "\=" to "%3D" and set "queryParamsAreURLEncoded"\="true" if you leave the other special URL characters unencoded they will be encoded by the HTTP Client.
Examples\: sysparm_limit\=10&sysparm_query\=severity\=1&sysparm_fields\=short_description,number,sys_id
 queryParamsAreURLEncoded - Specifies whether to encode (according to the url encoding standard) the queryParams. If you set "queryParamsAreURLEncoded"\=true and you have invalid characters in 'queryParams' they will get encoded anyway. If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Default value\: false
Valid values\: true, false
 queryParamsAreFormEncoded - Specifies whether to encode the queryParams in the the default format used by the apache http client library - form format. If this input is true then all characters will be encoded based on the queryParamsAreURLEncoded input.If queryParamsAreFormEncoded\=false all reserved chars are not encoded no matter of queryParamsAreURLEncoded input.The only exceptions are for space(' ')character which is encoded as %20 and + (plus) which is encoded as %20 and not encoded if queryParamsAreURLEncoded\=false. Check the "v2.0" folder description for more details.
Default value\: true. 
Valid values\: true, false
Example\: query\=test te%20@st will be encoded in query\=test%20te%20@st

Results
 returnResult - This will contain the response entity. In case of an error this output will contain the error message.
 document - This will contain the response body.
 exception - In case of success response, this result is empty. In case of failure response, this result contains the java stack trace of the runtime exception.
 statusCode - The HTTP status code.
Format\: 1xx (Informational - Request received, continuing process), 2xx (Success - The action was successfully received, understood, and accepted), 3xx (Redirection - Further action must be taken in order to complete the request), 4xx (Client Error - The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled), 5xx Server Error - The server failed to fulfil an apparently valid request)
Examples\: 200, 404
 responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline.
Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
 systemIdList - In case the response entity contains system IDs, they will be displayed in this result, in the form of a list.


Responses
 success - The operation completed without a runtime exception.
 failure - A runtime exception occurred. This may be due to incorrectly formated inputs (headers, proxy, queryParams, url).

Notes\:
1. In order to authenticate using an OAuth token\: 
 1.1. The headers input should contain the following header\: Authorization\:Bearer <OAuth_token>
 1.2. The username and password inputs should remain empty.
2. When the "queryParams" input is specified, the values entered in the "sysParamLimit", "sysParamQuery" and "sysParamFields" inputs are ignored.
 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.d46b0b8d-c42e-4989-a6c9-b792b8faeab9.description=<pre>
This flow sends, stores or displays a notification message according to your notification type selection. You can use this flow to select how to be notified about the outcome of other flows. 

Inputs\:
 notifyData - The content of the notification message.
 notifyMethod - The notification type. This value is not case sensitive.
Valid values\: Write to File, Email, Display or None
 subject - A summary of the notification content. 
 destination - The destination of the notification. You must specify a value for this input if "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’ or ‘Write to File’.
Valid values\: An email address or a file name
 notificationServer - The email server used to send the notification email message. If "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’, you must specify a value for this input.
 from - The email address of the sender of the notification email message. If "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’, you must specify a value for this input.
 serverPort - The notification service’s server port. This field’s value is used when the "notifyMethod" is ‘Email’, but it is optional.
Default value\: 25
 htmlEmail - The value should be true if the email is in rich text/HTML format. The value should be false to send the email in plain text format.
Default value\: true

Responses\:
 success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
 failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Note\:
 To schedule a flow that uses this flow, you need to supply all the required fields for the used notification method. For example, if "notifyMethod" is set to ‘File’, the "destination" input must also be specified.

Examples\:
 This is a valid input example for storing a notification message to a file\:
 notifyData\: notificationContent
 notifyMethod\: Write to File
 subject\: notificationSubject
 destination\: C\:\Program File\notification.txt
</pre> 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.e2b8453b-c8fb-4b99-82af-ddf72bd002b9.description=This flow is used to Update Changes.

Inputs
 host - The URL of the ServiceNow instance.
Format\: scheme\://domain
Example\: https\://dev10000.service-now.com
 authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server. The authentication is not preemptive\: a plain request not including authentication info will be made and only when the server responds with a 'WWW-Authenticate' header the client will send required headers. If the server needs no authentication but you specify one in this input the request will work nevertheless. The client cannot choose the authentication method and there is no fallback so you have to know which one you need. If the web application and proxy use different authentication types, these must be specified like in the Example model. 
Default value\: basic
Valid values\: basic, digest, ntlm, kerberos, any, anonymous, "" or a list of valid values separated by comma.
Example\: basic | basic,digest
 username - The ServiceNow username used to perform the request.
 password - The ServiceNow password used to perform the request.
 apiVersion - The API version with which the request will be sent. The call will be made using the latest API version when this input is left empty.
Example\: v1
 systemId - The System ID of the of the Change to be updated.
Example\: 71c7ac460f811200ff7eb17ce1050e7a
 requestBody - The string to include in the body of the request, in the format accepted by ServiceNow. In case more Change fields need to be addressed, they can be provided in the "requestBody" input. When a custom body is provided, the values provided in the inputs named "change<field_name>" will be ignored unless their reference is used in the new body.
Example\: {'short_description'\:'Example description','severity'\:'1','assigned_to'\:'46c1293aa9fe1981000dc753e75ebeee','state'\:'4'}
 changeShortDescription - The short description of the Change, in the form of a string.
 changeDescription - The description of the Change, in the form of a string.
 changeNumber - The number of the Change. Should contain the "CHG" prefix followed by 7 or more digits.
Example\: CHG0100001
 changeRequestedBy - The system ID of the entity that requested the Change.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 changeCategory - The Category name in the form of a string.
Example\: Software, Hardware
 changeConfigurationItem - The system ID of the Configuration Item. (CMDB CI)
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 changePriority - The Priority of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 5.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
 changeRisk - The risk of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 5.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
 changeImpact - The impact of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 3.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3
 changeApproval - The Approval status in the form of a string.
Valid values\: approved, requested, not requested yet, rejected
 changeType - The type of the Change in the form of a string.
Example\: Routine, Comprehensive
 changeState - The State of the Change, in the form of a positive integer. Each integer represents an Incident State as follows\: 1\=Open, 2\=Work in Progress, 3\=Closed Complete, 4\=Closed Incomplete, 7\=Closed Skipped.
Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 7
 changeAssignmentGroup - The system ID of the Assignment Group.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 changeAssignedTo - The system ID of the entity to which the Change should be assigned to.
Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978
 preemptiveAuth - If this field is 'true' authentication info will be sent in the first request. If this is 'false' a request with no authentication info will be made and if server responds with 401 and a header like WWW-Authenticate\: Basic realm\="myRealm" only then the authentication info will be sent.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 proxyHost - The proxy server used to access the web site.
 proxyPort - The proxy server port. Default value\: 8080. Valid values\: -1, and positive integer values. When the value is '-1' the default port of the scheme, specified in the 'proxyHost', will be used.
 proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy.
 proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the proxyUsername input value.
 trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL/TSL. A certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it.
Default value\: false
Valid values\: true, false
 x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker(Man In The Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option.
Default value\: strict
Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all
 trustKeystore - The pathname of the Java TrustStore file. This contains certificates from other parties that you expect to communicate with, or from Certificate Authorities that you trust to identify other parties. If the protocol (specified by the 'url') is not 'https' or if trustAllRoots is 'true' this input is ignored.
Default value\: <OO_Home>/java/lib/security/cacerts
Format\: Java KeyStore (JKS)
 trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If trustAllRoots is false and trustKeystore is empty, trustPassword default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
 connectTimeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in seconds. A timeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
Format\: an integer representing seconds
Examples\: 10, 20
 socketTimeout - The timeout for waiting for data (a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets), in seconds. A socketTimeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
Format\: an integer representing seconds
 useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls in a serializable session object therefore they will be available on a branch level (same subflow, same lane). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 keepAlive - Specifies whether to create a shared connection that will be used in subsequent calls. If keepAlive is false, the already open connection will be used and after execution it will close it. The operation will use a connection pool stored in a GlobalSessionObject that will be available throughout the execution (the flow and subflows, between parallel split lanes).
Default value\: true
Valid values\: true, false
 connectionsMaxPerRoute - The maximum limit of connections on a per route basis. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections per given route.
Default value\: 2
 connectionsMaxTotal - The maximum limit of connections in total. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections in total.
Default value\: 20
 headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:".
Format\: According to HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
Examples\: Accept\:text/plain
 contentType - The content type that should be set in the request header, representing the MIME-type of the data in the message body.
Default value\: "" (empty)
Examples\: "text/html", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded"
 requestCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP request body. If contentType is empty, the requestCharacterSet will use the default value. If contentType will include charset (ex.\: "application/json; charset\=UTF-8"), the requestCharacterSet value will overwrite the charset value from contentType input. This should not be provided for method\=GET, HEAD, TRACE
Default value\: ISO-8859-1
 responseCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP response. If responseCharacterSet is empty, the charset from the 'Content-Type' HTTP response header will be used. If responseCharacterSet is empty and the charset from the HTTP response Content-Type header is empty, the default value will be used. You should not use this for method\=HEAD or OPTIONS.
Default value\: ISO-8859-1

Results
 returnResult - This will contain the response entity. In case of an error this output will contain the error message.
 document - This will contain the response body.
 exception - In case of success response, this result is empty. In case of failure response, this result contains the java stack trace of the runtime exception.
 statusCode - The HTTP status code.
Format\: 1xx (Informational - Request received, continuing process), 2xx (Success - The action was successfully received, understood, and accepted), 3xx (Redirection - Further action must be taken in order to complete the request), 4xx (Client Error - The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled), 5xx Server Error - The server failed to fulfil an apparently valid request)
Examples\: 200, 404
 responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline.
Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).


Responses
 success - The operation completed without a runtime exception.
 failure - A runtime exception occurred. This may be due to incorrectly formated inputs (headers, proxy, queryParams, url).

Notes\:
1. The values stored in the fields of the Change will not be changed if the "change<field_name>" inputs are left empty.
2. The reference of the "change<field_name>" inputs should be removed from inside the "requestBody" input when they are deleted.
3. When more Change fields are required, than the ones exposed, you can add them as inputs and insert their reference in the Json found in the "requestBody" input.
4. In order to authenticate using an OAuth token\: 
 4.1. The headers input should contain the following header\: Authorization\:Bearer <OAuth_token>
 4.2. The username and password inputs should remain empty.
 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.ee6cee88-1f8f-4f84-95d5-704f8565d0f5.callout=This flow is used to retrieve the details of one or more Incidents in ServiceNow 3b706c37-a8e9-43e4-97c6-56266a1c94e1.ef247175-5029-4f90-a85b-035c637c4ca6.callout=This flow is used to Create Change Requests in ServiceNow
flow.name: ITSM Restart Server

staticBinding.value: Server Reboot initiated by HPE Operations Orchestration
